org.projectfloodlight.openflow.types

Class OFPortBitMap512

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.projectfloodlight.openflow.types.Masked<OFBitMask512>
      • org.projectfloodlight.openflow.types.OFPortBitMap512
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Comparable<Masked<OFBitMask512>>, OFValueType<Masked<OFBitMask512>>, PrimitiveSinkable

    @Immutable
public class OFPortBitMap512
extends Masked<OFBitMask512>
    User-facing object representing a bitmap of ports that can be matched on. This is implemented by the custom BSN OXM type of_oxm_bsn_in_ports_512. You can call set() on the builder for all the Ports you want to match on and unset to exclude the port. Implementation note: to comply with the matching semantics of OXM (which is a logical "AND" not "OR") the underlying match uses a data format which is very unintuitive. The value is always 0, and the mask has the bits set for the ports that should NOT be included in the range. For the curious: We transformed the bitmap (a logical OR) problem into a logical AND NOT problem. We logically mean: Inport is 1 OR 3 We technically say: Inport IS NOT 2 AND IS NOT 4 AND IS NOT 5 AND IS NOT .... The second term cannot be represented in OXM, the second can. That said, all that craziness is hidden from the user of this object.

    Usage

    OFPortBitmap is meant to be used with MatchField BSN_IN_PORTS_512 in place of the raw type Masked<OFBitMask512>.

    Example:

    : 
      OFPortBitMap portBitMap;
  Match.Builder matchBuilder;
  // initialize
  matchBuilder.setMasked(MatchField.BSN_IN_PORTS_512, portBitmap);
    Author:
    Andreas Wundsam <andreas.wundsam@bigswitch.com>

      • isOn

        public boolean isOn(OFPort port)
        Returns:
        whether or not the given port is logically included in the match, i.e., whether a packet from in-port port be matched by this OXM.

        public static OFPortBitMap512 of(OFBitMask512 mask)

        public Iterable<OFPort> getOnPorts()
